verses.text: For three years there was no war between Aram and Israel.
verses.comment: Introductory verse, matching the Masoretic text closely.

verses.text: In the third year, Jehoshaphat king of Judah went down to visit the king of Israel.
verses.comment: “Went down” is literal Hebrew. Jehoshaphat is king of Judah.

verses.text: The king of Israel said to his servants, “Do you know that Ramoth-Gilead belongs to us? Yet we have done nothing to take it out of the hand of the king of Aram.”
verses.comment: Ramoth-Gilead is in the Transjordan.

verses.text: He said to Jehoshaphat, “Will you go with me to fight at Ramoth-Gilead?” Jehoshaphat answered the king of Israel, “I am as you are, my people as your people, my horses as your horses.”
verses.comment: Maintains the parallel phrasing found in Hebrew.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, “Please ask for the word of the LORD first.”
verses.comment: Use of 'ask for the word of the LORD' for Hebrew 'darash et-pi Yahweh'.

verses.text: So the king of Israel gathered about four hundred prophets, and he said to them, “Should I go to war against Ramoth-Gilead, or should I refrain?” They said, “Go up, for the Lord will give it into the hand of the king.”
verses.comment: Refers to false prophets, not prophets of Yahweh.

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat said, “Is there not here another prophet of the LORD, by whom we may inquire?”
verses.comment: Jehoshaphat recognizes the need for a true prophet of Yahweh.

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “There is still one man by whom we may ask of the LORD, Micaiah son of Imlah, but I hate him, for he never prophesies good about me, only evil.” But Jehoshaphat said, “Let not the king say so!”
verses.comment: Close to Hebrew; 'evil' could also be translated 'disaster'.

verses.text: Then the king of Israel called an officer and said, “Bring Micaiah son of Imlah quickly.”
verses.comment: ‘Officer’ is literal for Hebrew ‘saris’, typically a court official.

verses.text: Now the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah were sitting, each on his throne, dressed in royal robes, at the threshing floor at the entrance of the gate of Samaria. All the prophets were prophesying before them.
verses.comment: Details like 'threshing floor' and clothing match original.

verses.text: Zedekiah son of Chenaanah made horns of iron for himself and said, “This is what the LORD says: ‘With these you will gore the Arameans until they are destroyed.’”
verses.comment: Symbolic action of horns as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: All the prophets were prophesying, saying, “Go up to Ramoth-Gilead and you will succeed; for the LORD will give it into the king's hand.”
verses.comment: ‘You will succeed’ for Hebrew 'tsalach'.

verses.text: The messenger who went to call Micaiah spoke to him, saying, “See, all the prophets are speaking favorably to the king with one voice. Let your word be like theirs, and speak favorably.”
verses.comment: Messenger attempts to influence Micaiah.

verses.text: But Micaiah said, “As the LORD lives, I will speak only what the LORD says to me.”
verses.comment: ‘As the LORD lives’ is a solemn oath formula.

verses.text: When he came to the king, the king said to him, “Micaiah, should we go to Ramoth-Gilead to battle, or should we refrain?” He answered him, “Go up and succeed, for the LORD will give it into the hand of the king.”
verses.comment: Micaiah at first repeats the majority’s message, most likely ironically.

verses.text: But the king said to him, “How many times must I make you swear to tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the LORD?”
verses.comment: 'Make you swear' for Hebrew 'Shavua'.

verses.text: Then Micaiah said, “I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains, like sheep that have no shepherd. And the LORD said, ‘These have no master; let each return to his home in peace.’”
verses.comment: ‘Sheep that have no shepherd’ is a common OT idiom.

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “Did I not tell you that he would not prophesy good about me, but only evil?”
verses.comment: ‘Evil’ for Hebrew 'ra'.

verses.text: Micaiah said, “Therefore hear the word of the LORD: I saw the LORD sitting on his throne, with all the host of heaven standing by him on his right and left.
verses.comment: Host of heaven denotes spiritual beings.

verses.text: The LORD said, ‘Who will entice Ahab, so that he will go up and fall at Ramoth-Gilead?’ One said one thing and another said another.
verses.comment: ‘Entice’ for Hebrew 'patah', meaning to deceive or persuade.

verses.text: Then a spirit came forward and stood before the LORD and said, ‘I will entice him.’
verses.comment: Word ‘spirit’ (ruach) reflects supernatural agency.

verses.text: He said, ‘How?’ And the spirit answered, ‘I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets.’ He said, ‘You are to entice him, and you will succeed. Go and do it.’
verses.comment: ‘Lying spirit’ matches Hebrew.

verses.text: So now, the LORD has put a lying spirit in the mouth of all these prophets of yours, and the LORD has decreed disaster for you.”
verses.comment: 'Disaster' for Hebrew 'ra'.

verses.text: Then Zedekiah son of Chenaanah came up and struck Micaiah on the cheek and said, “How did the Spirit of the LORD pass from me to speak to you?”
verses.comment: Physical violence in response to oracle.

verses.text: Micaiah said, “Behold, you shall see on that day when you go into an inner room to hide yourself.”
verses.comment: 'Inner room' literal for Hebrew.

verses.text: The king of Israel said, “Take Micaiah and return him to Amon the governor of the city and to Joash the king’s son,”
verses.comment: Amon and Joash are officials; 'return him' implies previous imprisonment.

verses.text: and say, ‘This is what the king says: “Put this man in prison and feed him with only bread and water until I come in peace.”’”
verses.comment: 'Bread and water' as minimal rations.

verses.text: Micaiah said, “If you do indeed return in peace, the LORD has not spoken by me.” And he said, “Hear, all you people!”
verses.comment: 'Hear, all you people' marks a public witness.

verses.text: So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah went up to Ramoth-Gilead.
verses.comment: Simple narrative continuity.

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “I will disguise myself and go into battle, but you wear your robes.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
verses.comment: Attempt to avoid being targeted as king.

verses.text: Now the king of Aram had commanded his thirty-two chariot commanders, saying, “Do not fight with anyone, small or great, but only with the king of Israel.”
verses.comment: 'Small or great' is typical Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: So when the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they said, “Surely he is the king of Israel.” So they turned aside to fight against him, but Jehoshaphat cried out.
verses.comment: Jehoshaphat's cry probably saved his life.

verses.text: When the chariot commanders saw that he was not the king of Israel, they turned away from him.
verses.comment: Active switch in focus based on recognition.

verses.text: But a certain man drew his bow at random and struck the king of Israel between the scales of his armor. So the king said to his chariot driver, “Turn around and carry me out of the battle, for I am wounded.”
verses.comment: 'At random' is literal Hebrew 'in simplicity.'

verses.text: The battle grew fierce that day, and the king was propped up in his chariot facing the Arameans; the blood from the wound ran into the bottom of the chariot, and that evening he died.
verses.comment: Narrative is straightforward; details match Hebrew closely.

verses.text: A cry went up throughout the army as the sun was setting: “Every man to his city, and every man to his own country!”
verses.comment: As in Hebrew, the scattering of soldiers.

verses.text: So the king died and was brought to Samaria; they buried the king in Samaria.
verses.comment: Simple statement, matching Hebrew.

verses.text: They washed the chariot by the pool of Samaria, and the dogs licked up his blood, and the prostitutes washed themselves there, according to the word of the LORD that he had spoken.
verses.comment: ‘Prostitutes’ literal for Hebrew; word of Yahweh fulfilled.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Ahab, and all that he did, and the ivory house which he built, and all the cities he built, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Reference to historical records.

verses.text: So Ahab slept with his fathers, and Ahaziah his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: 'Slept with his fathers' is a common Hebrew idiom for death.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat son of Asa became king over Judah in the fourth year of Ahab king of Israel.
verses.comment: Chronological notation.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Azubah daughter of Shilhi.
verses.comment: Age and duration match Hebrew numerals.

verses.text: He walked in all the ways of Asa his father; he did not turn aside from them, doing what was right in the eyes of the LORD. However, the high places were not taken away; the people still sacrificed and burned incense on the high places.
verses.comment: High places refer to illicit worship sites.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was at peace with the king of Israel.
verses.comment: Text matches original closely.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, and his might that he showed, and how he made war, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Reference to historical record.

verses.text: He removed from the land the rest of the male shrine prostitutes who remained from the days of his father Asa.
verses.comment: 'Male shrine prostitutes' for Hebrew 'kedeshim'.

verses.text: There was no king in Edom at that time; a deputy ruled as king.
verses.comment: 'Deputy' for Hebrew 'natsib'; means appointed official.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat made ships of Tarshish to go to Ophir for gold, but they did not go, for the ships were wrecked at Ezion-Geber.
verses.comment: ‘Ships of Tarshish’ for long sea voyages.

verses.text: Then Ahaziah son of Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, “Let my servants go with your servants in the ships.” But Jehoshaphat was not willing.
verses.comment: ‘Not willing’ matches negative Hebrew.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat slept with his fathers and was buried with them in the city of David, his father; so Jehoram his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Traditional formula for royal death and succession.

verses.text: Ahaziah son of Ahab became king over Israel in Samaria in the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and he reigned over Israel two years.
verses.comment: Chronological details preserved.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD, and walked in the way of his father and in the way of his mother and in the way of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who made Israel sin.
verses.comment: ‘Made Israel sin’ for Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: He served Baal and worshiped him and provoked the LORD, the God of Israel, to anger, just as his father had done.
verses.comment: Concludes Ahab’s dynasty in keeping with Hebrew.
